introPages.title: What are fixed expressions?
introPages.body:
Fixed expressions (or fixed phrases) are set phrases – the words always go together in a fixed form. You cannot change the wording: in fact is always in fact, not in a fact or in the fact.

The gap in Part 2 often completes a fixed expression. You need to recognise the phrase and supply the missing word – usually a preposition, article, or small connecting word.

Familiarity is the best way to get to know them. Read and notice them in context; learn them as whole phrases. See the full list of fixed phrases in the Reference section of this programme.

introPages.title: They are fixed – you can't change them
introPages.body:
Fixed expressions cannot be altered. You cannot add or remove words, or swap one word for another.

❌ in a fact → ✓ in fact. ❌ as result → ✓ as a result. ❌ in the other hand → ✓ on the other hand.

Each phrase has one correct form. Learn it exactly. The gap tests whether you know the phrase.

introPages.title: Common fixed expressions
introPages.body:
Cause/result: as a result, for this reason, in order to, for the sake of

Contrast/add: on the other hand, in addition, as well as, in spite of, in contrast

Examples: for instance, for example, such as

Other: in fact, in terms of, with regard to, by means of, on behalf of, in case, in time, take turns

introPages.title: Common mistakes
introPages.body:
❌ in a fact / in the fact → ✓ in fact

❌ as result → ✓ as a result

❌ in the other hand → ✓ on the other hand

❌ such like → ✓ such as

❌ for an instance → ✓ for instance

❌ in term of → ✓ in terms of

❌ by mean of → ✓ by means of

❌ in behalf of → ✓ on behalf of

❌ for sake of → ✓ for the sake of

introPages.title: Rules for the gap
introPages.body:
• Read the whole sentence – the phrase may span the gap. Look before and after.
  • Recognise the phrase. Do you know in order ___? → to. ___ the other hand? → on.
  • Don't guess from grammar alone – fixed expressions must be learned.
  • Use the Fixed phrases list in the Reference section to learn and revise.

mcQuiz.question: In It was ___ fact the case, which word fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: The phrase is 'in fact'. No article.

mcQuiz.question: In as ___ result, which word fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: As a result – the article 'a' is required.

mcQuiz.question: In ___ the other hand, which preposition fits?
In countries such ___ France, which word fits?
In ___ instance, consider this, which word fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: For instance. No article. 'For' starts the phrase.

mcQuiz.question: In in terms ___ cost, which preposition fits?
In ___ behalf of the company, which preposition fits?
mcQuiz.explanation: On behalf of. Not 'in behalf of'.

shortQuestions.question: We did it in a fact.
shortQuestions.explanation: The phrase is 'in fact'. No article.

shortQuestions.question: It happened as result.
shortQuestions.explanation: As a result – the article 'a' is required.

shortQuestions.question: In the other hand, I disagree.
accepted: on the other hand, i disagree

shortQuestions.question: Countries such like France and Spain.
accepted: countries such as france and spain

shortQuestions.question: For an instance, take the case of …
accepted: for instance, take the case of
shortQuestions.explanation: For instance. No article. Not 'for an instance'.

shortQuestions.question: In term of cost, it's cheaper.
accepted: in terms of cost, it's cheaper

shortQuestions.question: We travelled by mean of train.
accepted: we travelled by means of train

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why can't you change the words in a fixed expression?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: Fixed expressions are conventional – native speakers use them in one form only. Changing a word (in a fact, as result) makes it wrong. They must be learned as complete units.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Why is familiarity the best way to learn them?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: You learn them by seeing and hearing them in context. Reading, practice tests, and exposure help you recognise the phrase when the gap appears. Memorising the Reference list helps too.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: What is the difference between in time and on time?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: In time = with enough time to spare, before a deadline. On time = punctually, at the scheduled time. Both are fixed; the preposition cannot be swapped.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Give three fixed expressions with in and three with on.
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: In: in fact, in order to, in addition, in spite of, in terms of, in case, in time. On: on the other hand, on behalf of, on the basis of, on account of.

optionalQuestionsBank.question: Where can you find the full list of fixed phrases in this programme?
optionalQuestionsBank.suggested: In the Reference section – click the 'Fixed phrases' tab. The list shows phrases that often appear in Part 2.
